description: Markdown is a alternative to other markup languages such as HTML. There is a version that is a little more 'fancy' called GitHub Flavored Markdown. In this series, you will find out what GitHub-Flavored Markdown is as well as how to accomplish quick format tasks that simplify creating structure and some styling.
descriptionMD: Markdown is a alternative to other markup languages such as HTML. There is a version that is a little more 'fancy' called GitHub Flavored Markdown. In this series, you will find out what GitHub-Flavored Markdown is as well as how to accomplish quick format tasks that simplify creating structure and some styling.
name: Learn GitHub Flavored Markdown
subtitle: Easy Document Formatting

episodes.description: Markdown is a alternative to other markup languages such as HTML. There is a version that is a little more 'fancy' called GitHub Flavored Markdown. In this series, you will find out what GitHub-Flavored Markdown is as well as how to accomplish quick format tasks that simplify creating structure and some styling.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.170
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.170 --> 00:00:09.460
Welcome, everyone, to your
Learn GitHub-Flavored Markdown series.

3
00:00:09.460 --> 00:00:10.920
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:10.920 --> 00:00:13.341
Today, I'd like to introduce Mr.
Justin Dennison.

5
00:00:13.341 --> 00:00:15.590
He's gonna be the one guiding
you through this topic.

6
00:00:15.590 --> 00:00:19.370
So Justin, I've gotta ask,
what should I expect from this series?

7
00:00:19.370 --> 00:00:21.400
>> So
this series is fairly entry level and

8
00:00:21.400 --> 00:00:26.090
is meant to give you a working proficiency
of writing in GitHub-Flavored Markdown.

9
00:00:26.090 --> 00:00:29.420
Some of the things that you'll learn
how to do are creating headings,

10
00:00:29.420 --> 00:00:33.260
adding images, adding links,
adding tables.

11
00:00:33.260 --> 00:00:38.650
Well, in addition to that, further,
more specific, like adding code blocks,

12
00:00:38.650 --> 00:00:43.460
adding little code snippets, and,
well, adding to-do lists to your

13
00:00:43.460 --> 00:00:48.770
markdown documents to further organize and
help you get the look that you hope for.

14
00:00:48.770 --> 00:00:52.320
>> Okay, so who has really
been the target audience, or

15
00:00:52.320 --> 00:00:55.080
what should we expect as far as
how this show has been tailored?

16
00:00:55.080 --> 00:00:56.370
Like what are we looking at here?

17
00:00:56.370 --> 00:00:57.850
>> This is very introductory.

18
00:00:57.850 --> 00:01:00.050
It is meant for kind of a grab bag, right?

19
00:01:00.050 --> 00:01:01.360
You can just pick and choose.

20
00:01:01.360 --> 00:01:02.900
I need to know how to create headings.

21
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:05.170
I need to know how to create links.

22
00:01:05.170 --> 00:01:07.030
How do I make a table of contents?

23
00:01:07.030 --> 00:01:12.100
Well, those are also probably links, so
you just can grab those individual pieces.

24
00:01:12.100 --> 00:01:15.510
There are a few shows that
are tailored toward developers or

25
00:01:15.510 --> 00:01:17.440
people who are working with code snippets.

26
00:01:17.440 --> 00:01:21.360
But, by and large, whether you're a
writer, whether you're someone technical,

27
00:01:21.360 --> 00:01:25.780
or not, this has something for you if
you're writing documents in Markdown.

28
00:01:25.780 --> 00:01:28.670
>> Should I expect to get some kind of
certification from this traning, or

29
00:01:28.670 --> 00:01:31.140
are we really looking at skill set based?

30
00:01:31.140 --> 00:01:33.910
>> This is definitely
a skill set based training.

31
00:01:33.910 --> 00:01:38.780
It is, as I said, meant to be
a reference material for you where

32
00:01:38.780 --> 00:01:43.050
maybe you don't watch it from beginning
to end every time, or even at all.

33
00:01:43.050 --> 00:01:45.020
You go,
I need to know how to make headings,

34
00:01:45.020 --> 00:01:46.930
I need to know how to make a table.

35
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:50.780
You go and watch that particular episode
to accomplish the tasks that you need to

36
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:53.840
accomplish with your
respective Markdown documents.

37
00:01:53.840 --> 00:01:54.870
>> Great, that sounds awesome.

38
00:01:54.870 --> 00:01:58.065
And if you agree, then stay tuned.

39
00:01:58.065 --> 00:02:02.881
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate getting set up to write markdown files. This setup is going to make getting immediate rendering feedback a breeze.
episodes.title: Writing Markdown

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrates how you can use GitHub-flavored markdown to italicize text in your writing.
episodes.title: Italicizing Text

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrates how you can use GitHub-flavored markdown to emphasize text in your writing.
episodes.title: Bolding Text

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin demonstrates how you can use GitHub-flavored markdown to strikethrough text in your writing.
episodes.title: Striking Through Text

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate creating a link to an external site.
episodes.title: Adding an External Link

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate how to create different sized of headings within a Markdown document.
episodes.title: Creating Headings

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes explore creating a blockquote using Markdown syntax.
episodes.title: Creating a Blockquote

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes explore how to add an underline to a heading in a file.
episodes.title: Creating a Heading with Underline

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate creating a link to another document contained in the project.
episodes.title: Adding an Internal Link

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee demonstrate creating a lists in markdown.
episodes.title: Creating Lists

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee add an image to a markdown document.
episodes.title: Adding an Image

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee create an image that is also a link.
episodes.title: Creating an Image with a Link

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee leverage the GitHub flavor to arrange information in a table.
episodes.title: Creating a Table

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee take a cue from developer's to demonstrate inlining code in the Markdown file.
episodes.title: Inlining Code

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee take additional cues from the developers of the world and demonstrate adding more code than a single line to the Markdown document.
episodes.title: Creating a Code Block

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee demonstrate some of the more powerful portions of GitHub Markdown to create a task list that can be used to keep track of all of the things to get done.
episodes.title: Creating a Task List
